What counts as code for an ability?

It's pretty much certain that they're not hand coding every ability from scratch, and instead they're calling more general stuff (e.g. things for projectiles) that wasn't written specifically for that champion, so most of the heavy lifting codewise is done separate from the ability itself. If they're really on the ball with their coding, they can get writing abilities for a new champion to just a few lines of new code (or even a single line) in principle.

And are we only talking about the gameplay impacting code, or are we also looking at all the stuff involved with hooking up audio/animation/etc?

Is "Reallylongchampionname_q_ability(stuff)" more code than "champ#_q_ability(stuff)"?

(Riot has an engineering website which often has articles that discuss a lot of behind the scenes insights into how their code base works if you really want to dig into things.)

____

All that said, trist Q does seem like a reasonable contender, but basic skill shots might be 'simpler' if you consider the rapid fire buff that (that has a duration that the game needs to track) as part of the ability.
Basic skill shots might need distance to be coded in too which is the same thing. And if I'm wrong, who has the simplest skill shot?

If we want to remove distance as a factor, global ults (jinx/ashe/ezreal) come to mind. Ezreal is probably easier since it doesn't even stop on hitting a champion.

It sortof depends on some of the answers to what counts. If your ability applies a buff that doesn't previously exist in the game, do you then need to write code for that buff as part of the ability, or do you write the ability "apply_rapidfire_buff(rank)", then elsewhere actually code up the buff as something that exists independent of that ability?

Ashe W is sortof 9 simple projectiles in one. Veig Q is straight forward as well. Cait Q might also be easy. They all have some complications from their passives (or in caits case, w interaction) depending on if that stuff counts as part of those abilities, or if those complications are actually just part of the passive(/w).
